title: Roving8612
author: Roving8612
content: I came across an activity from this addresshttps://mempool.space/address/bc1qm5fc6p6je6dlt2082vyprfxxyzkcd5xxnnwff3which is sending very small amounts to a large number of single purpose addresses - the pattern here is that they identify an address holding some bitcoin, create a new address which matches the receiving one in the last few characters and send a dust transaction. Clearly there is automation here, waiting for low transaction fees to execute, so good level of sophistication. I'm just wondering what could be the reason behind this activity??

comments.author: pooya87
comments.body: It's a weird form of attack which has been going on for 3-4 years at least. You can read more about it in the topic I started a while back, other users added interesting information there: https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=5466445.0Basically the attacker hopes that the receiver decides to reuse the same address and seeing the similar looking address they copy the attacker's address by mistake and send their coins/change to that one so that the attacker can make profit!

comments.author: pooya87
comments.body: Quote from: SensitiveEyes on February 19, 2025, 02:32:25 PMIt could take years. Is there a success rate ratio. How many times would an attacker have to perpetrate the routine to get lucky once?I haven't seen any extensive research where someone follows these coins and reports back. It would require a simplified blockchain analysis where you'd first find all these outputs (where sender's address looks similar to the receiver's) then simply check if there is any case of coins going from the "victim's" address to the attackers.Logically the success rate of this attack has to be very low because normally if someone wants to copy their own address they'll go to their addresses tab which exists under various names in all wallets. They don't go to their receive tab or history tab to copy the receiving address of a transaction they'd received before.

I don’t mind it though because I don’t think anyone would ever fall for it, and now that transaction fees are so low and the price of Bitcoin has gone up so much, I have been using the “dust” to pay for my transaction fees. comments.author: nullama
comments.body: My guess is that it's a part of the attack, just broadly applying this to every address seen.The other part would be to release some kind of malware or virus that would switch the contents of the copy/paste clipboard whenever it detects one of these addresses, or something similar to that.Therefore, the unsuspected user would copy his or her address, the virus would catch it and replace it with the attacker address. Then when pasted, most people at most simply check the beginning or the end of the address, which you mention the attacker copies. So, it would be OK.Transaction sent, then they realize later the funds never arrived. They double check and realized the address was different.It does seem a bit sophisticated, but when you think about it, a single transaction could be a large sum of money, so it's probably worth it for the hacker.
